reviews.review:
Portal 2 is certainly very interesting game. 

At the core of gameplay lays portal mechanic that we could experience in Porta l1 - it was not modified or extended in any way but rather devs found new ways to make it interesting. Those include mostly adding new materials with special physical properties which considerably raised complexity of puzzles - some of them became really clever and took me considerable time to complete. Sadly there is also type of puzzle that took me a lot of time and caused a lot of frustration - many times player is put in huge space where the task seems to be finding surfaces to put portal on. I don't think this kind of chellange is very interesting, after some time I ended up running around and shooting portal gun at everything.

Furthermore I can't fail to praise devs for great implementation of other mechanics. In Portal 2 besides using portals player can only move around, jump and use action - it's not much but I have never ever had issue with controlling character. Everything is very responsive, physics have clear rules, and hitboxes for interactions are always forgiving - which is great because at the core Portal is a puzzle game, not a platformer.

Storywise Portal2 is very consistent with it's predecessor. Plot twists are surprising and items in world we travel in methodically fill in the gaps in our understanding of what testing facility actually is and how did it come to this point of decay. Story wraps up nicely, I hoped for some twist at the end (imagine going up the elevator only to learn that world was overtaken by the turrets and GLADOS was actually the only other humanlike being left) but there is nothing to complain about really. GLADOS character creation deserves huge price. In key moments the game provides hints at first and later actual information of who she really is - that helped me build deeper relation with this character. Voice acting is on point too. Sadly plot has some holes, such as seeing crow at the very bottom of facility (literally the only other than protagonist animal seen in game) that just moved GLADOS in our path... that's a bit tacky.

Game world in portal is huge and beautiful, only a bit too repetitive. Some rooms and places seems to exist only because they needed some space for player but make no sense whatsoever. This is especially true in backstage of test facility - one that stood out the most for is room with just 3 turrets in it facing toward backstage. Rarely did the rooms had any lore significance which made many of them a bit mundane. Also physics in some parts just blew my mind - this is the case especially for liquids that many times failed to obey law of physics - example of this would be destroying liquid pipes near the end of the game. Bad things aside game world of Portal2 is very original and breathtaking. Idea of panels and in place construction of testing sites, starting location, and retro fill of old testing facility all impressed me a lot.

Overall gameplay of portal is nicely paced and seamless. Lengthy puzzles are interlaced with more dynamic runaway scenes where music does great job of creating sense of urgency (more so than actual gameplay). Devs (as in previous part) do outstanding job by introducing new ideas of using portals up till the very end.

I highly recommend this game but only after finishing first part!
98.76% postive. Do I need to say more

I got both games for 3.00 and i love both of them!

INGREDIENTES
1 lata de creme de leite
1 lata de leite (a mesma medida da lata de creme de leite)
2 latas de leite condensado
2 gemas
2 colheres de maisena
3 colheres de chocolate em pó ou achocolatado
biscoito maisena
leite para molhar os biscoitos
raspas de chocolate (opcional)
manteiga sem sal ou margarina, só para dar o ponto
MODO DE PREPARO
Primeiro, pegue a lata de leite condensado, as gemas, a maisena e o leite.

Coloque no fogo e deixe até que fique um creme, reserve.

Coloque a segunda lata de leite condensado com um pouco de margarina e o chocolate.

Deixe no fogo até ficar um creme tipo brigadeiro.

Desligue o fogo e junte com o creme de leite.

MONTAGEM:
Coloque primeiro o creme branco.

Em seguida, mergulhe os biscoitos no leite e coloque sobre o creme branco.

Depois, coloque o creme preto e acrescente as raspas de chocolate sobre ele.

Deixe no congelador durante 2 horas.
